title: CWE-79: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Details
excerpt: Detailed explanation of CWE-79, how XSS works, the three main types of XSS (Reflected, Stored, DOM-Based), and the resulting attack consequences.

full_content.heading: CWE-79 Definition
full_content.text: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) is a web security vulnerability that allows an attacker to compromise the interactions that users have with a vulnerable application. The core issue is CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation. The main goal of an XSS attack is to circumvent the same-origin policy of the browser.

full_content.heading: How XSS Works
points: Attackers inject malicious JavaScript into a vulnerable web page.
The victim's browser executes the malicious script.
The attacker compromises the user's interaction with the application, violating the Same-Origin Policy.

items.subtitle: Reflected XSS (Non-Persistent / Type 1)
items.detail: Malicious scripts are injected into a website's response to a user's request. The injection happens through manipulated parameters in URLs, forms, or client-side requests. The payload is not stored on the server.

items.subtitle: Stored XSS (Persistent / Type 2)
items.detail: Malicious scripts are stored on the server (e.g., in databases, comment sections). This is persistent because any user who views the compromised page will execute the script.

items.subtitle: DOM-Based XSS (Type 0)
items.detail: The vulnerability exists in the client-side code (Document Object Model) rather than the server response. The attack is executed entirely within the victim's browser.

items.subtitle: Self-XSS
items.detail: Tricks users into running malicious JavaScript in their browser's console. No direct website vulnerability is exploited, but successful attacks can lead to account compromise.

full_content.heading: Consequences of XSS Attacks
points: Session Hijacking and Cookie Theft (used to gain access to the application).
Malware Distribution or Redirection to other malicious websites (drive-by downloads).
